content:
Added "loop T write answer" to stub generator.
Also made some minor changes in wording in Input and Output sections.
edit: removing the constraint "C <= R" which does not hold in Test/Validator 5.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good

Thanks everyone for your help and suggestions, and thank you JohnCM and Husoki for the approvals. Only 8 hours left to validate, so if one more person wouldn't mind taking a look and approving, I'd be much obliged!
a good puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, non-trivial solution for the hard cases.

Tried using Python and got stuck!
Managed to get only the basic and easy test cases right, which means my code is working but not optimal enough.

I did layer by layer calculation using the sum of two values of the previous two rows. I think the difficulty is that such a method is insufficient for the input row size, and some mathematical intuition other than that given by the puzzle needs to be used in order to solve it.

Definitely worthy of the "very hard" difficulty.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The number theory problem is interesting and there's a lot of opportunity for a combination of dealing with large integers, plus optimization based on pencil-and-paper mathematics.
Hey everyone, the formatting of the test cases has been fixed, and validators have also been added. Thanks again for all the suggestions.
The last sentences of your description got mangled: "greater than the row. than As the"
This seems really hard but really fun though! Well done

Oops.  I think you need to rearrange the test case data sets.  As I understand it, they are supposed to be in test, validator pairs with each pair testing the same data range or edge/corner case types, but with different numbers to prevent hardcoding.

The user should be able to expect that if Validator #3 fails, there's input similar to Test#3 that can fail, even if that specific combination wasn't in Test 3.

All the "basic" and "easy" tests work using a one-minute Python no-brainer, so I'll plan to approve once the test cases line up.
Really challenging!

What should I do to get people to vote on this? In my opinion, this is a really interesting problem, and based on the comments and upvotes I've received thus far, it would seem that plenty of others agree.

If it can be improved, or if there's something I could be doing so that the community is more likely to notice it, then I'd be very interested in knowing that. I've also considered writing an in-depth editorial explaining the logic and mathematical concepts required to pass all the test cases -- would this help?

Also, just a friendly reminder that this is not a Clash of Code submission, so there is no reason why you should impose any sort of time limit on yourself for solving it.

Thanks! :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
What's the deal with the 15 minutes? Why so many people seem concerned about solving it in <15min? Love the problem btw! Hopefully it'll get accepted soon.
Wow! I need to try some hard puzzles first! Looks great and suitably challenging.

I find this intriguing and I'm drawn to want to solve it.
I could certainly not solve it and code it within 15 minutes. I would tend to reach for pen and paper.
I think, if I grasped the math, turning it into code would be fairly simple, but I could be wrong! It would be satisfying, though! If I only had the time.

Cool problem, I was able to write a solution to do basic and easy in under 15 minutes. I used python and cached the pascal rows on the fly. Solving the harder ones makes me thing i should precompute as many rows as possible. If c were the same for a given problem set one could do optimization there. Either that or ditch python. If there is a mathematical property one could exploit for computation speed that would be great but I don't know it. If there isn't I think it is worth asking if including the puzzles with quadrillions is worth it.

I would clarify on your input what P R and C are rather than only have them buried in the description.

Edit: I am not level 20 so I can neither approve nor reject.
Nobody has any thoughts on this problem? Is the problem statement clear enough?  Has anyone attempted to code their own solution?
I just noticed that I must have copied the wrong test case data for "R != C (hard)", as the inputs all have R equal to C. Just a heads up; I will fix this test case soon.

Is it possible to use different fonts in the problem description, specifically one with fixed widths? The vertical alignment of the ASCII graphics is a bit off due to the slight variations in character widths. Hopefully it's clear enough for the time being!

You can use the backquote !
And others for bold, yellow and blue for more highlight...
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/writing-the-statement

There is, indeed, a mathematical trick! I'll probably write a description of it in detail at some point, but essentially it involves dividing the fractal into "levels" according to the maximum power of P that will fit within each horizontal and vertical range (so if R = C = 40 and P = 3, the maximum power that can fit within the fractal is 3^3 = 27). The total number of shaded cells for any level n is always (1 + 2 + 3... + P)^n, so these values can easily be precomputed and summed up in O(n) time. 

That's all the easy part. :) From here, there are two particularly challenging aspects of the problem:

1: Handling cases where R is not a power of P.
2: Handling cases where C != R.

For cases where R is not a power of P but C = R, let P^k be the highest power of P that can fit within R rows. Once we've found a k such that P^(k + 1) > R, we then count all the shaded cells up until row P^k, and then find the maximum value y such that P^k * y <= R (with y being an integer in the range [1 to P]). We add the counts for these rows and then reduce R by P^k * y (think of it as if we're "chopping off the top" of the triangle). This method is executed recursively, reducing the size of the triangle at each step until we've reached level -1.

When R != C, we essentially do the same thing horizontally by finding the maximum multiple x of P^k that fits within the width of the triangle (P^k * x <= C). This is the part of the problem where things start to get pretty complicated, since you need to be quite careful about combining the counts of the different horizontal and vertial "cuts" of the fractal without over-counting. The recursive calls can also get quite expensive here, so DP/memoization is necessary. 

The implementation of all of this can be found in the Solve() function of my solution code.

Anyway, thanks for the feedback!

Thanks! And I was wondering about this too... many of the "Very Hard" leveled problems on this site took me months to solve 100%, and I can't imagine I'm the only one! Anyway, I'll resubmit it again soon with a full-length algorithmic/mathetmatical editorial.

I suspect it's the last last item on the approval checklist: "You have coded your own working solution."  That can be a difficult step on hard and very-hard problems.  I'm pretty new around here, though.  Maybe there's an understanding about trusting a reference solution if it agrees with a naive solution on smaller values?  That's my plan, anyway, and you can expect approval from me soon if that goes well.
Fixed, thanks a lot for pointing this out!
Fixed, thanks!
I personally cannot approve your puzzle because I'm not lvl 20, but be sure I'd do it if it was in my power :)
Hmm, I have a fully-working, efficient solution posted. Are you not able to see it?

Yes--and I mentioned the "reference solution" in my comment--but that's not what the approval question asks me.  It asks if I have coded my own solution.  And I said that was just a guess; and I said that it wasn't a block to my approval given the reference solution.

As a solver, not (yet?) a composer, I still think that matching test cases and validator cases is a big deal, though.  See my later comment.
OK, I understand. I'll definitely look into your suggestion about the test cases. Thanks!
It is because many people don't bother to notice that this is a classic puzzle and assume that all contributions are Clash of Code.
Excellent, thank you!
